GENERAL REGULATIONS
§ 70.01  DEFINITIONS.
   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning.  All other terms used in this chapter
shall have the meanings assigned to such terms in the motor vehicle laws of the
state or their ordinary and common meanings.
   BUS.  Any motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten passengers and
used for the transportation of persons.
   COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLE.  Any motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight
rating (GVWR) greater than 10,000 pounds, designed or used for the
transportation of property, not including a passenger bus, passenger
automobile, motorcycle or pickup truck.
   CURB.  The lateral lines of a roadway, whether constructed above grade or
not, that are intended for vehicular travel.
   DOUBLE PARKING.  Standing or parking a vehicle on the roadway side of a
vehicle already stopped, standing or parked at the curb.
   FREEWAY.  Any limited access expressway or highway within the city,
including the entrances and exits leading to and from the through traffic lanes
of that expressway or highway.
   HOUSE TRAILER.  A vehicle without motive power, designed to be drawn by a
motor vehicle, and designed primarily as living quarters for persons, whether
permanently or for temporary or recreational purposes, but not including
manufactured homes or mobile homes.
   LOADING ZONE.  A space adjacent to a curb, reserved for the exclusive use of
vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.
   MEDIAN STRIP.  The area or portion of a divided street, road or highway
within the city, separating the two roadways of that street, road or highway,
including the curb, if any, at the outer edge of that area.
   MOBILE HOME.  Living quarters equipped or used for sleeping and eating,
which may be moved from one location to another over a public street by being
pulled behind a motor vehicle.
   MOTOR HOME.  Living quarters, propelled by a motor vehicle, equipped or used
for sleeping and eating, which may be moved from one location to another over a
public street, not including a camper mounted on a pickup truck, or a van
designed to carry ten or fewer passengers.
   NEGLIGENCE.  The want of ordinary care and caution as a person of ordinary
prudence would use under like circumstances.
   PARK OR PARKING.  To stand an occupied or unoccupied vehicle, other than
temporarily, while loading or unloading merchandise or passengers.
   OPERATOR.  Any person in control of a vehicle, including a railroad train or
vehicle being towed.
   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE.  A self-propelled vehicle designed for use as living
quarters for persons, whether permanently or for temporary or recreational
purposes.
   STAND OR STANDING.  To halt an occupied or unoccupied vehicle, other than
temporarily, while receiving or discharging passengers.
   SERVICE ROAD.  An auxiliary roadway adjacent to a freeway, expressway or
major thoroughfare, which is used by traffic desiring access to abutting
property, and by traffic seeking ingress to or egress from the adjacent
freeway, expressway or major thoroughfare.
   TRAILER.
      (1)   A vehicle without motive power designed to be drawn by a motor
vehicle, secured to the motor vehicle by a pole, reach, or boom, and designed
to carry or transport cargo or property;
      (2)   A vehicle without motive power designed to be drawn by a motor
vehicle, constructed so that part of its weight and load rests on the other
vehicle, and designed to carry or transport cargo or property; or
      (3)   A vehicle without motive power designed to be drawn by a motor
vehicle, that is more than 20 feet long, and has commercial equipment built
into or onto it.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.02  PARKING ON PUBLIC STREETS.
   It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this section for
any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name
of or operated by that person to do the following:
   (A)   Double park.  Double park at any point on the streets or alleys of the
city.
   (B)   Obstructions from parked vehicles.  Stop or park upon or adjacent to a
public street or alley so that any portion of the vehicle, including but not
limited to, any objects carried in or upon the vehicle, protrude into the main-
traveled portion of that street or alley.
   (C)   Maximum parking time.  Park on any street or alley in the city for a
period of time longer than 48 hours or the time period stated on signs posted
by authority of this chapter.
   (D)   Stopping, standing and parking regulated. Stop, stand or park at any
time upon any public street, alleyway, other public place or fire lane, when
signs are erected or curbs are painted giving notice that stopping, standing or
parking is prohibited.
   (E)   Parking for certain purposes.  Park upon any public street, alley or
public property of any nature whatsoever in the city for the purpose of:
      (1)   Displaying the vehicle for sale;
      (2)   Washing, greasing, cleaning, polishing, waxing, changing oil or
repairing the vehicle, except for repairs necessitated by an emergency; or
      (3)   Selling or exhibiting property of any nature.
   (F)   Parking certain vehicles.
      (1)   The following types of parking and standing for certain vehicles
shall be unauthorized:
         (a)   Park, if the vehicle is a truck tractor, road tractor, trailer,
semitrailer, pole trailer, bus, motor home, mobile home or any commercial motor
vehicle, as these terms are defined in §
70.01 and Tex. Transportation Code § 541.201, upon a public street, alley,
parkway, boulevard measuring less than 38 feet in width, or public property.
Nothing in this division shall authorize the parking of mobile homes in any
location, public or private, unless pursuant to a permitted use authorized by
the zoning ordinance.
         (b)   Leave, park or stand any truck tractor, road tractor,
semitrailer, bus, truck or trailer with a rated capacity in excess of five
tons, according to the manufacturer's classification, upon property within any
area zoned as either a dwelling district or apartment district, according to
the zoning ordinance. This division shall not prevent the parking or standing
of such vehicles in such zoned areas for the purpose of expeditiously loading
and unloading passengers, freight or merchandise, but not otherwise.
         (c)   Leave, park or stand any truck tractor, road tractor,
semitrailer or other commercial vehicle on the driver’s side of any one-way
alley situated within the central business district.
      (2)   This division (F) shall not apply to:
         (a)   Street construction, maintenance and repair equipment;
         (b)   Trucks, equipment, trailers and vehicles used by public service
utility companies, when engaged in repairing or extending public service
utilities;
         (c)   Motor buses, when taking on or discharging passengers at
customary bus stops;
         (d)   Other vehicles, when actually parked at a designated loading
zone;
         (e)   Municipal vehicles in the course of performing city business; or
         (f)   When it is lawful to park a commercial motor vehicle for the
purpose of accepting or delivering transportable goods.
         (g)   It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this division
that the vehicle had a mechanical defect, making it unsafe to proceed further,
in which event, it shall be lawful to stand or park the vehicle during the time
necessary to make emergency repairs.
   (G)   Parking off pavement, roadway or parking area. Parking off the
pavement, main-traveled portion of the roadway or a designated or permitted
parking area onto any property without the effective consent of the owner. It
is an affirmative defense to the prosecution that the parking off the pavement,
main-traveled portion of the roadway or designated or permitted parking area
was required due to an emergency malfunction of the motor vehicle, and that
there was no other safe place to operate the vehicle, or that it was required
due to an order by a peace officer. It is an exception that the motor vehicle
is a municipal vehicle performing municipal duties, or public utility vehicle
performing service within an easement.
   (H)   Parking on sidewalks. Park any motor vehicle or trailer across or upon
any sidewalk for pedestrians.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.03  OPERATION OF MOTORCYCLES OR MOTOR VEHICLES ON CERTAIN PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorcycle or motor vehicle
on any utility easement, vacant lot, other unpaved private property or church
parking lot, paved or unpaved, not owned by the operator, or his or her
immediate family, without the express written consent of the owner carried on
the operator’s person.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.04  DISABLED PARKING.
   (A)   Defined. DISABLED PARKING SPACES are those parking spaces marked as
required by state statutory requirements, whether on private property or public
property, including streets.
   (B)   Use.  The use of any disabled parking space shall be unlawful except
for those persons parking vehicles being operated by or for a person with
disabilities, which vehicles display:
      (1)   A valid disabled parking placard issued pursuant to Tex.
Transportation Code Ch. 681;
      (2)   A valid license plate issued pursuant to Tex. Transportation Code §
504.201 or § 504.202; or
      (3)   A license plate or placard that:
         (a)   Bears the international symbol of access; and
         (b)   Is issued by a state or by a state or province of a foreign
country to the owner or operator of the vehicle for the transportation of a
person with a disability.
   (C)   Enforcement.
      (1)   The Chief of Police is authorized to appoint persons to have
authority to file a charge against a person who commits an offense under Tex.
Transportation Code Ch. 681.
      (2)   A person appointed under this section must:
         (a)   Be a United States citizen of good moral character who has not
been convicted of a felony;
         (b)   Take and subscribe to an oath of office that he or she will
faithfully perform the duties assigned; and
         (c)   Successfully complete a training program of at least four hours
in length developed by the Police Department.
      (3)   A person appointed under this section:
         (a)   Is not a peace officer;
         (b)   Has no authority other than the authority applicable to a
citizen to enforce a law other than this chapter; and
         (c)   May not carry a weapon while performing duties under this
section.
      (4)   A person appointed under this section is not entitled to
compensation for performing duties under this section, or to indemnification
from the city or the state for injury or property damage the person sustains,
or liability the person incurs, in performing duties under this section.
      (5)   Neither the city nor the state are liable for any damage arising
from an act or omission of a person appointed under division (C)(1) in
performing duties under this section.
         (a)   Application.  This section and Tex. Transportation Code §
681.011 apply to a parking space or area for persons with disabilities on
private property that is designated in compliance with the identification
requirements referred to in Tex. Transportation Code § 681.009(b).
         (b)   Offenses, penalties.  Offenses are defined and penalties are
provided for by Tex. Transportation Code § 681.011.
         (c)   Towing.  Any vehicle not displaying the proper disabled license
plate, tag or device may be towed from a handicapped parking space defined by
division (A) of this section, at the expense of the owner of that vehicle, and
may be impounded until all towing and storage charges are paid.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.05  TEMPORARY PERMITS.
   (A)   A temporary permit for up to 48 hours, to park on a street or public
right-of-way, can be obtained from the City Administrator, upon a showing that
travel on the street or public right-of-way will not be dangerously blocked or
inhibited for emergency vehicles or regular traffic.
   (B)   The terms of §
70.02 shall not be construed to apply where the parking is permitted in
conjunction with temporary special events open to the public, which may be
approved from time to time by the City Council.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.06  PARKING WITHIN A RESIDENTIAL OR MULTI-FAMILY ZONED AREA.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park or allow the following to be parked on
any private property located within a residential or multi-family zoned area:
      (1)   A commercial vehicle; or
      (2)   A trailer.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to street construction, maintenance, and
repair equipment; trucks, equipment, trailers, and vehicles used by public
service utility companies engaged in repairing or extending public service
utilities; motor buses when taking on or discharging passengers at customary
bus stops; other vehicles when actually parked at a designated loading zone;
municipal vehicles in the course of performance of town business; or a
commercial vehicle that is actually accepting or delivering portable goods.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.07  PARKING ON HARD-SURFACED AREAS AND RESIDENTIAL LOTS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or to allow to be parked
on any property under his or her control any automobile, light truck,
motorcycle, camper, or boat on any portion of a front yard or side yard
adjoining a street of any area zoned and used as one-family, two-family, or
multi-family dwelling purposes, unless:
      (1)   The area is a part of a hard-surfaced driveway or parking area;
      (2)   The area is a part of a gravel driveway bordered by cement curbing
or similar permanent border;
      (3)   The area is part of a required driveway that provides access to a
garage, carport, or off-street parking area required by a zoning ordinance; or
      (4)   The area is part of a side yard enclosed by a screening fence at
least six feet in height, and so constructed that no person can see through
into the area surrounded by the fence.
      (5)   No restrictions are implied on the back of the property past the
rear building.
   (B)   The term “hard surfaced” as used herein is defined in §
151.027(D)(2) of the zoning ordinance.
   (C)   This subchapter shall not apply to any presently existing gravel
driveway, but if any change or abandonment of use of the driveway area occurs,
then the owner or occupant of the property may not thereafter revert to use of
same for parking of vehicles without meeting the terms and provisions of this
subchapter.
   (D)   For purposes of this section, DRIVEWAY shall mean the area between the
curb cut or drive approach from a public street or alley, to a garage, carport
or rear yard vehicle storage area.
   (E)   Parking spaces and any adjoining private driveways shall be
constructed as described in §
151.027(D)(2) of the zoning ordinance. The paved surface shall be two inches or
more in thickness, shall not exceed one-half inch in height above the adjacent
unpaved surface, and shall be located perpendicular to the curb cut or drive
approach. On nonconforming lots without paved parking spaces and driveways
existing as of the effective date of this chapter, the parking spaces and
driveways shall only be located perpendicular to the curb cut or drive
approach.
   (F)   All vehicles shall be driven and parked so as to completely rest upon
a paved surface or driveway. On nonconforming lots without paved parking spaces
and driveways existing as of the effective date of this chapter, all vehicles
shall be driven and parked so as to completely rest upon the unpaved parking
spaces or driveways as provided in this section, or in the side yard adjacent
thereto. No parking spaces shall be permitted in the remaining front yard
portion, unless it is paved in accordance with division (B) above.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.08  PARKING ON A DRIVEWAY, PARKING LOT, OR OFF-STREET PARKING AREA.
   It shall be unlawful to park or allow to be parked any commercial vehicle,
trailer, recreation vehicle, house trailer, boat, bus, or any trailer designed
to be towed and used for commercial purposes on a driveway, parking lot, or
other off-street parking area in such a manner that any portion of same extends
past the front or side property line of the property, and into property that is
publicly-owned or to which a public easement has been granted.  The prohibition
applies even though a street, curb, or other public improvement may not extend
to and abut the surveyed property line.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.09  CONFLICTS.
   Nothing in this subchapter shall be deemed or construed to allow the parking
of a recreational vehicle or house trailer within a residential or multi-family
zoned area except in strict conformity with other ordinances specifically
addressing the parking.  To the extent this subchapter may conflict with other
ordinances specifically addressing the parking, the other ordinances shall
control.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.10  PUBLICATION.
   The City Secretary is instructed to publish this subchapter as provided by
law.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.11  EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect from and after its
publication as required by law and it is so ordained.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.12  PARKING PROHIBITED ON FARM TO MARKET HIGHWAY 1886.
   (A)   It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck,
motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any other type of vehicle on
or along the improved an unimproved portions of the public right-of-way for
Farm to Market Highway 1886 as it runs through the town limits.  The RIGHT-OF-
WAY FOR FARM TO MARKET HIGHWAY 1886 is hereby defined as being 50 feet on
either side of the center of Farm to Market Highway 1886.
   (B)   Signs shall be installed to inform the traveling public of the fact
that no parking at any time shall be allowed along the right-of-way.
   (C)   It is provided, however, that this prohibition shall not apply to the
driver of any vehicle that becomes disabled to such an extent that it is
impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving the disabled vehicle as
far as possible off the paved portion of the highway.  It is further provided,
however, that a disabled vehicle must be removed from the highway right-of-way
within 48 hours after it has been parked and left.
   (D)   In a prosecution for an offense involving the stopping, standing, or
parking of an unattended motor vehicle, it shall be presumed that the
registered owner of the vehicle is the person who stopped, stood, or parked the
vehicle at the time and place the offense occurred.  The registered owner of
the vehicle may rebut this presumption by showing that he or she did not stop,
stand or park the vehicle, and by identifying the party who did so.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.13  ENFORCEMENT; NOTICE.
   (A)   Any police officer for the town shall have the authority to require
the immediate abatement and removal of any illegally parked vehicle as provided
herein.  The town or a wrecker service under the direction of a police officer
may, without the consent or knowledge of the owner or operator of the vehicle,
remove and store the vehicle at a vehicle storage facility at the vehicle
owner’s expense.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, the last registered owner of the vehicle
is responsible for all costs incurred under or other consequences resulting
from this section.
   (C)   The town shall give written notice by certified mail, return receipt
requested, within two days after the date of removal of the vehicle, to:
      (1)   The last address that the registration records of the Texas
Department of Transportation show for the owner of the vehicle, or if the
vehicle is registered in another state, the last address that the appropriate
agency of that state shows for the owner of the vehicle; and
      (2)   Every lien holder recorded under Tex. Transportation Code Ch. 501,
as may be amended from time to time.
   (D)   The notice shall:
      (1)   Describe the vehicle with sufficient particularity to identify the
vehicle;
      (2)   Identify the location of the facility that is storing the vehicle
(including a valid and working telephone number for the facility);
      (3)   Inform the owner and lien holder of the right to claim the vehicle
not later than 170 days from the date of the notice, upon the payment of all
towing, preservation, notification and storage charges;
      (4)   State that the owner or lien holder’s failure to claim the vehicle
within the period specified is:
         (a)   A waiver by that person of all rights, title and interest in the
vehicle; and
         (b)   Consent to the disposal of the vehicle as provided by state law.
   (E)   The town may dispose of the vehicle in any manner allowed by state
law.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS
§ 70.20  SPECIAL EXCEPTION AVAILABLE.
   A person desiring to park a commercial vehicle or trailer on private
property located within a residential or multi-family zoned district, as
prohibited by §§
70.01 through
70.09, may do so only by obtaining a special exception from the City Council as
provided herein.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)  Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.21  SUBSTANTIAL ECONOMIC HARM.
   No person may obtain a special exception to the parking prohibition, unless
and until the person can demonstrate to the City Council that the prohibition
is causing and shall continue to cause substantial economic harm to that
person.  The fact that a person may have to pay parking or other fees at a
storage or other parking facility, if the prohibition remains in effect, shall
not constitute substantial economic harm.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.22  REQUEST FOR SPECIAL EXCEPTION.
   (A)   In order to obtain a special exception, a person shall file a written
request for same.  The written request shall include:
      (1)   The name and address of the person requesting the exception;
      (2)   The address of the property where an exception to the prohibition
against parking is desired;
      (3)   A description of the vehicle or trailer made subject of the
exception;
      (4)   A statement of the economic harm being suffered by the applicant;
      (5)   The proposed length of time for the exception to exist;
      (6)   The place where the vehicle or trailer is to be parked, including a
description of the pavement or other material on which it is to be parked; and
      (7)   The name and address of each property owner or occupant of property
located on the same street within 200 feet of the property for which the
exception is desired, or the town block on which the property is located,
whichever is more.  If the property is a corner property, then the 200-foot
requirement shall be used for each street of the intersecting streets.
   (B)   At the time of the filing of the written request, the person shall
also pay a fee of $100.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.23  NOTICE OF REQUESTED EXCEPTION.
   The City Secretary shall mail a notice of the requested exception to each
person set out in the application, setting out that an exception has been
requested, a description of the vehicle or trailer, and the date and time of
the hearing on the exception before the City Council.  The notice shall be sent
at least ten days before the date of the hearing.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.24  HEARING.
   At the hearing before the City Council, the applicant shall be permitted to
speak and present the application, and all other persons who wish to do so
shall be permitted to speak for or against the application.  Any person shall
also be permitted to present any written petition for or against the exception
signed by the property owners who received notice.  The City Council and/or the
Mayor may set and announce limits for the time of presentation or speaking by
all persons, and the other rules as are deemed necessary and proper.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.25  GRANTING OF EXCEPTION.
   (A)   If a majority of the City Council attending the meeting find that
substantial economic harm will result to the applicant if the prohibition
against parking remains in effect and vote to allow an exception, then the
exception shall be granted.
   (B)   The City Council may impose conditions for granting of the exception,
such as but not limited to, fencing, places on the property where the vehicle
or trailer may be parked, the type of material on which the vehicle or trailer
may be parked, and limitations of the regularity of driving the vehicle or
pulling the trailer into and out of the property.
   (C)   If more than 50% of the persons who receive the required notice of the
filing of the exception object to same (either by appearing or signing a
written petition objecting to the exception), then the exception shall not be
granted, unless at least two-thirds of the members of the City Council present
at the hearing vote in favor of same.
   (D)   If any exception is granted, then the City Council shall also set the
length of time for which the exception is granted.  No exception may be granted
for a period in excess of two years.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.26  EXCEPTION WITH CONDITIONS; VIOLATIONS; FORFEITURE; TERMINATION.
   (A)   If an applicant is granted an exception with conditions, and the
applicant violates a condition, the City Secretary or Chief of Police shall
send a notice of the violation, with a warning that if any condition is
violated again, the exception shall be administratively forfeited and the
prohibition shall again be in effect as to the property.
   (B)   If a second violation occurs, then the exception shall be forfeited
and withdrawn by giving written notice to the holder of the exception.  The
holder of the exception may appeal the forfeiture to the City Council by giving
written notice of the appeal no later than 15 days after the date of the notice
of forfeiture.  The City Council may overrule the forfeiture, but only if it is
found that the two violations did not, in fact, occur.
   (C)   If the exception is forfeited, then the holder thereof may not request
another exception for one year from the date the forfeiture becomes final.
   (D)   The exception shall terminate at the expiration of the time set by the
City Council, unless the holder shall renew same by filing for renewal
thereof.  The procedures and requirements set out above shall apply to any
renewal application.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
§ 70.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Whenever in this chapter an act is prohibited or is made or declared
to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in this chapter the
doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be
unlawful, and no specific penalty is otherwise provided in this code of
ordinances, the violation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500,
provided, however, that no penalty shall be greater or less than the penalty
provided for the same or a similar offense of the laws of the state.
   (B)   Each day a violation of this chapter or of any ordinance continues
shall constitute a separate offense.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or fail
to comply with any provisions of this chapter, irrespective of whether or not
the verbiage of each section contains the specific language that such violation
or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense. Any person who shall
violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or any of the provisions of a
permit issued pursuant thereto, or who shall fail to comply with the terms
thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, on conviction thereof, be
fined in the sum not to exceed $500. The violation of each separate provision
thereof shall be considered a separate offense. Each day’s continuance of a
failure to comply therewith shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 346, passed 2-16-2015)
CHAPTER 71:  TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Schedule
   
I.   Speed limits
   
II.   Stop and yield signs
   
III.   Engine braking
SCHEDULE I.  SPEED LIMITS.
   (A)   (1)   The speed limit on FM Road 1886, otherwise known as Confederate
Park Road, beginning from the eastern most boundary of the town located at the
south or southeast bound service road intersection with State Highway 199, and
running approximately 1.76 miles along FM Road 1886, to the western border of
the Town of Lakeside shall be 45 mph.  All vehicles of any kind or nature
traveling along that portion of FM Road 1886 shall not exceed the speed limit
set out herein.  There shall be excepted from the requirement of speed,
emergency vehicles running under emergency conditions and the other exceptions
as allowed and set out in state law.
      (2)   Signs posting the speed limit shall be installed to inform the
traveling public of the speed limit in the manner as to give full notice of the
speed limit and as may be required by state law.
      (3)   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or
fail to comply with any provisions hereof, irrespective of whether or not the
verbiage of each section hereof contains the specific language that the
violation or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense.  Any person who
shall violate any of the provisions of this division (A) or any of the
provisions of a permit issued pursuant hereto, or who shall fail to comply with
the terms hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, on conviction
thereof, be fined in the sum not to exceed $500, or the lesser amount that may
be required by state law, and the violation of each separate provision hereof
shall be considered a separate offense.
      (4)   The Town Secretary is here directed and authorized to cause
publication of this division (A) as required by law.
      (5)   This division (A) shall be in full force and effect from and after
its publication as required by law, and it is so ordained.
   (B)   (1)   Upon basis of an engineering and traffic investigation
heretofore made as authorized by the provisions of Tex. Transportation Code, §
545.353, Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, the following prima facie
speed limits hereafter indicated for vehicles are hereby determined and
declared to be reasonable and safe; and the speed limits are hereby fixed at
the rate of speed indicated for vehicles traveling upon the named streets and
highways, or parts thereof, described as follows.
         (a)   State Highway 199 (Southwest Frontage Road) Tarrant County. 
From Station 520+48.5 (east town limits of Lakeside, also being the town limits
of Fort Worth) northwesterly 1.081 to Station 577+57.5 (north town limits of
Lakeside, being also the town limits of Fort Worth) at 40 mph.
         (b)   1.   The maximum speed limit on Vanshire Road, east and west,
within the limits of the town shall be 25 miles per hour.  All vehicles of any
kind or nature traveling on Vanshire Road shall not exceed the speed limit set
out herein.  There shall be excepted from such requirement of speed, emergency
vehicles running under emergency conditions and such other exceptions as
allowed and set out in state law.
            2.   Signs posting the speed limit shall be installed to inform the
traveling pubic of the speed limit in such manner as to give full notice of the
speed limit as may be required by state law.
         (c)   The maximum speed limit on Lakeridge Road within the limits of
the town shall be 25 miles per hour.  All vehicles of any kind or nature
traveling on Lakeridge Road shall not exceed the speed limit set out herein. 
There shall be excepted from such requirement of speed, emergency vehicles
running under emergency conditions and such other exceptions as allowed and set
out in state law.
         (d)   1.   With the exceptions noted herein below, all streets in the
Town of Lakeside shall have a maximum speed limit of 30 miles per hour.
            2.   The maximum speed limit on the following streets within the
town limits shall be shown below:
               a.   Vanshire Road, east and west, shall be 25 miles per hour.
               b.   Lakeridge Road shall be 25 miles per hour.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or
fail to comply with any provisions of this schedule, irrespective of whether or
not the verbiage of each section hereof contains the specific language that
such violation or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense.  Any person
who shall violate any of the provisions of this schedule or any of the
provisions of a permit issued pursuant hereto, or who shall fail to comply with
the terms hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, on conviction
thereof, be fined in the sum not to exceed $500, or such lesser amount that may
be required by state law, and the violation of each separate provision hereof
shall be considered a separate offense.
      (3)   Whenever construction of a state-maintained highway within the town
limits of the Town of Lakeside is begun, and the Texas Department of
Transportation establishes speed limits within the construction zones by
commission minute order, then the speed limits as are established by the
commission minute order are hereby adopted by the Town of Lakeside as the speed
limit in the construction zones.
(Ord. 65-B, passed 7-6-1989; Ord. 154, passed 1-8-1993; Ord. 281, passed 10-11-
2007; Ord. 294, passed 5-14-2009; Ord. 295, passed 5-14-2009)
SCHEDULE II.  STOP AND YIELD SIGNS.
   (A)   (1)   (a)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
intersection of Copperwood and Farm to Market Road Highway 1886 (Confederate
Park Road) governing movement from Copperwood onto Farm to Market Road 1886.
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, moped, bicycle,
or any other mode of transportation of persons or property approaching Farm to
Market Road 1886 while driving on Copperwood shall come to a complete stop at a
clearly marked stop line at the intersection of the two roadways, or, if there
is not a clearly marked stop line, then at a place nearest the intersection of
the two streets specified above where the stop sign is posted.  After stopping,
the operator shall grant immediate use of movement to persons or vehicles of
any kind or nature on Farm to Market Road 1886 in obedience to the stop sign
and after stopping may proceed only when the intersection can be safely entered
without interference or collision with vehicular or pedestrian traffic using
Farm to Market Road 1886.
         (c)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
intersection of Silver Hill Court and Silver Creek Road governing movement from
Silver Creek Court onto Silver Creek Road.
         (d)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, moped, bicycle,
or any other mode of transportation of persons or property approaching Silver
Creek Road while driving on Silver Hill Court shall come to a complete stop at
a clearly marked stop line at the intersection of the two roadways, or, if
there is not a clearly marked stop line, then at a place nearest the
intersection of the two streets specified above where the stop sign is posted. 
After stopping, the operator shall grant immediate use of movement to persons
or vehicles of any kind or nature on Silver Creek Road in obedience to the stop
sign and after stopping may proceed only when the intersection can be safely
entered without interference or collision with vehicular or pedestrian traffic
using Silver Creek Road.
      (2)   Any person violating any provision of this division (A) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas law.
      (3)   This division (A) shall be published as required by law and shall
then be in full force and effect after the date of its publication and it is so
ordained.
   (B)   (1)   (a)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
intersection of Brook Baker Blvd and Holt Street governing movement on Brooks
Baker Blvd.
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, moped, bicycle,
or any other mode of transportation of persons or property shall come to a
complete stop at a clearly marked stop line at the intersections specified
above or if there is not a clearly marked stop line, then at a place nearest
the intersection of the two streets specified above where the stop sign is
posted, at each of the locations described hereinabove and shall grant
immediate use of the intersection to other vehicular or pedestrian traffic in
obedience to the stop sign and after stopping, may proceed only when the
intersection can be safely entered without interference or collision with
vehicular or pedestrian traffic using a different street or roadway.
      (2)   Any person violating any provision of this division (B) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas law.
      (3)   This division (B) shall be published as required by law and shall
then be in full force and effect after the date of its publication and it is so
ordained.
   (C)   (1)   (a)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
following locations:
            1.   In the northbound lane of Silver Creek Road at its
intersection with F.M. 1886 (also known as Confederate Park Road); and
            2.   In the southbound lane of Silver Spring Lane at its
intersection with F.M. 1886 (also known as Confederate Park Road).
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, moped, bicycle,
or any other mode of transportation of persons or property shall come to a
complete stop at a clearly marked stop line at the intersections specified
above or if there is not a clearly marked stop line, then at a place nearest
the intersection of the two streets specified above where the stop sign is
posted, at each of the locations described hereinabove and shall grant
immediate use of the intersection to other vehicular or pedestrian traffic in
obedience to the stop sign and after stopping, may proceed only when the
intersection can be safely entered without interference or collision with
vehicular or pedestrian traffic using a different street or roadway.
      (2)   Any person violating any provision of this division (C) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas law.
      (3)   This division (C) shall be published as required by law and shall
then be in full force and effect after the date of its publication and it is so
ordained.
   (D)   (1)   (a)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
following locations:
            1.   In the eastbound lane of Mountain Ridge Court West at its
intersection with Western Trails Road;
            2.   In the westbound lane of Mountain Ridge Court East at its
intersection with Western Trails Road;
            3.   In the eastbound lane of Trailside Court West at its
intersection with Western Trails Road; and
            4.   In the westbound lane of Trailside Court East at its
intersection with Western Trails Road.
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, moped, bicycle,
or any other mode of transportation of persons or property shall stop at a
clearly marked stop line or if there is not a clearly marked stop line, then at
a place nearest the intersection, at each of the locations described
hereinabove and shall grant immediate use of the intersection to other
vehicular or pedestrian traffic in obedience to the stop sign and after
stopping, may proceed only when the intersection can be safely entered without
interference or collision with vehicular or pedestrian traffic using a
different street or roadway.
      (2)   Any person violating any provision of this division (D) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas law.
      (3)   This division (D) shall be published as required by law and shall
then be in full force and effect after the date of its publication and it is so
ordained.
   (E)   (1)   (a)   Stop signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
following locations:
            1.   In the westbound lane(s) of traffic on the F.M. 1886 bridge
crossing Highway 199 at its intersection with the eastbound lanes of traffic on
the south service road of Highway 199;
            2.   In the eastbound lanes of traffic in the 8900 block of the
south service road of Highway 199 at its intersection with F.M. 1886;
            3.   In the eastbound lane of traffic in the 9200 block of F.M.
1886 at its intersection with the south service road of Highway 199; and
            4.   In the northbound lane of traffic of the access road to and
from the First Baptist Church of Lakeside (also called Glory Road) at its
intersection with the 9250 block of F.M. 1886.
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, or moped shall
stop at a clearly marked stop line or if there is not a clearly marked stop
line, then at a place nearest the intersection, at each of the locations
described hereinabove and shall grant immediate use of the intersection to
other vehicular or pedestrian traffic in obedience to the stop sign and after
stopping, may proceed only when the intersection can be safely entered without
interference or collision with vehicular or pedestrian traffic using a
different street or roadway.
      (2)   (a)   Yield signs conforming to state law shall be placed at the
following locations:
            1.   In the eastbound lanes of traffic in the 8900 block of the
south service road of Highway 199 at its intersection with the off ramp from
Highway 199 to F.M. 1886;
            2.   In the right-hand eastbound lane of traffic in the 9200 block
of F.M. 1886 at its intersection with the south service road of Highway 199
preparatory to making a right turn onto the service road; and
            3.   In the right-hand eastbound lane of traffic in the 8900 block
of the south service road of Highway 199 at its intersection with F.M. 1886
preparatory to making a right turn on to F.M. 1886.
         (b)   An operator of a vehicle, motor vehicle, truck, or moped shall
slow to a speed reasonable under the existing conditions before reaching the
yield sign at each of the locations described hereinabove and shall yield the
right-of-way to a vehicle or pedestrian in or approaching the intersection on
another street or roadway and may proceed only when the intersection can be
safely entered without interference or collision with vehicular or pedestrian
traffic using another street or roadway.
      (3)   Any person violating any provision of this division (E) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas law.
      (4)   This division (E) shall be published as required by law and shall
then be in full force and effect after the date of its publication and it is so
ordained.
   (F)   (1)   Stop signs shall be erected at the following street locations
within the corporate town limits of the Town of Lakeside, Texas:
On Aquilla Drive at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Paint Brush Road at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Lakeridge Road at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Townes Drive at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Vanshire Road West at its intersection with F.M. 1886
At all four corners of the intersection of Lake Ridge Road and Crestridge Road
and Crestridge Circle
At all four corners of the intersection of Emily Drive and Lake Ridge Road
At all four corners of the intersection of Claiborn Street and Brooks Baker
Avenue
On Brookes Baker Avenue at its intersection with Watercress Road
On Crestridge Road at its intersection with Aauilla Drive
On the northbound and southbound lanes of Paint Brush Road at its intersection
with Aquilla Drive
On Holt Street at its intersection with Rankin Road
On Claiborn Street at its intersection with Rankin Road
On Vanshire Road East at its intersection with Live Oak Road
On Live Oak Road at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Old Gate Road at its intersection with Silver Creek Road
On Western Trails Road at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Tamarron Drive at its intersection with F.M. 1886
On Lakeside Oaks Circle at its intersection with Farm to Market Road 1886
On the eastbound lane of F.M. 1886 at its intersection with the south frontage
road of SH 199
On Townes Drive at its intersection with Lake Ridge Road
On Crestridge Circle at its intersection with the 300 block of Lake Ridge Road
On Rocky Ridge Terrace at its intersection with Lake Ridge Road
On Meandering Court at its intersection with Watercress Road
On Wren Haven Drive at its intersection with Holt Street
On Wren Haven Drive at its intersection with Claiborn Street
On Oakwood Court at its intersection with Farm to Market Road 1886
On Mary Jane Lane at its intersection with Farm to Market Road 1886
The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection named above controlled by a
stop sign shall stop and then proceed only when the driver of the vehicle may
safely enter the intersection without interference or collision with other
traffic at the intersection.
 
      (2)   Yield right-of-way signs shall be erected at the following street
locations within the corporate town limits of the Town of Lakeside, Texas:
On Stone Drive at its intersection with Aquilla Drive
On Cacti Drive at its intersection with Aquilla Drive
On Stone Drive at its intersection with Crestridge Drive
On Larch Street at its intersection with Brookes Baker Avenue
On Live Oak Road at its intersection with Vanshire Road West
On Rocky Ridge Terrace at its intersection with Crestridge Circle
On Cacti Drive at its intersection with Crestridge Drive
On Larch Street at its intersection with Claiborn Street
The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection named in this division (F)
(2) controlled by a yield right-of-way sign shall yield the right-of-way to all
other vehicles at the intersection and proceed thereafter only when the driver
of the vehicle may safely enter the intersection without interference or
collision with other traffic at the intersection.
 
      (3)   Any person violating any provision of this division (F) shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in
an amount not to exceed the maximum amount set or required by State of Texas
law.
      (4)   This division (F) shall become effective and be in full force and
effect immediately after adoption and publication as provided by law and when
appropriate signs prescribed by this division (F) are erected.

passed 10-14-2004)
SCHEDULE III.  ENGINE BRAKING.
   (A)   Engine-exhaust braking prohibited.  No person may use an engine-
exhaust braking system while operating a motor vehicle within the corporate
limits of the town.  For the purpose of this schedule, the term ENGINE-EXHAUST
BRAKING SYSTEM means an engine-exhaust braking system device which converts
diesel-engine power into an air compressor and when engaged operates to slow
the vehicle, and is sometimes described or referred to as “Jake brakes”.
   (B)   This schedule shall be cumulative of all provisions of ordinances of
the Town of Lakeside, Texas, except where the provisions of this schedule are
in direct conflict with the provisions of such ordinances, in which event the
conflicting provisions of such ordinances are hereby repealed.
   (C)   It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Town Council that the
phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of this schedule are
severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this
schedule shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of
any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect
any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of
this schedule, since the same would have been enacted by the Town Council
without the incorporation in this schedule of any such unconstitutional phrase,
clause, sentence, paragraph or section.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or fail
to comply with any provisions hereof, irrespective of whether or not the
verbiage of each section hereof contains the specific language that such
violation or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense.  Any person who
shall violate any of the provisions of this schedule or any of the provisions
of a permit issued pursuant hereto, or who shall fail to comply with the terms
hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, on conviction thereof, be
fined in the sum not to exceed $500, or such lesser amount that may be required
by state law, and the violation of each separate provision hereof shall be
considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 325, passed 7-14-2011)
