SECTION 1 - GENERAL
1.1  General Information
1.1.1  Opening Statement.
   Any person subdividing or developing land shall be responsible for obtaining
legal approval and recording of the subdivision. The subdivider/developer shall
also be responsible for installing all improvements necessary to provide
access, utilities and protection to the owners, future owners and the public.
1.1.2  City.
   The Town of Lakeside is a Type A, General Law City in the State of Texas. A
general law city is one that is less than 5,000 in population and is therefore
not eligible to have a Home Rule charter. The City is a legal incorporation of
the State of Texas (with defined geographical city limits) and is thereby bound
by the state laws applicable to such cities. For the purpose of this
subdivision ordinance, most of the relevant state statutes are codified in the
Local Government Code. A Mayor and City Council govern the City.
1.1.3  Growth.
   In general, most cities grow over time. Therefore, the State provides
procedures by which a City can expand its boundaries and regulate development
to provide for orderly growth. Such procedures include annexation, zoning and
platting. These procedures allow for the consistent and adequate extension of
public facilities such as roads, utilities, drainageways, parks, etc.
1.1.4  Annexation.
   The process of Annexation expands the exterior boundaries of the city.
Properties adjacent to the current City may be annexed into the city limits by
voluntary petition followed by the formal annexation process. In limited cases,
land may be annexed involuntarily. Often, City services are not offered to
areas that have not been annexed. Therefore, such areas desiring city services
shall be required to annex (if adjacent to the existing city limits) prior to
platting.
1.1.5  Zoning.
   The State and most cities recognize that orderly growth includes the
grouping of certain uses in common areas and the buffering from one use to the
next. This helps prevent busy, noisy or other objectionable uses from being
constructed next to quiet residential areas. It also encourages high use
facilities (high traffic, large utility use, etc.) to be grouped where there is
access to adequate infrastructure facilities. The City regulations for Zoning
are contained in the Zoning Ordinance for the Town of Lakeside, latest
revision. Zoning is enforced within the City Limits but not in the ETJ.
1.1.6  Extraterritorial Jurisdiction.
   Since the planning for growth includes areas not currently in the city, the
state allows each city a buffer zone in which they can control platting outside
of their city limits. This buffer is called Extraterritorial Jurisdiction
(ETJ). The City has platting control within its ETJ, but not zoning control.
The ETJ width is determined by the State based on a city's population. The
current ETJ extension of Lakeside is one-half (1/2) mile from the city limits.
   In addition, the ETJ allows for an orderly process when two cities start to
grow together. By ETJ agreements, cities can allocate potential overlap areas
among the affected cities.
1.1.7  Subdivisions.
   Whether inside the city limits or in the ETJ, larger tracts of land are
divided into smaller tracts to accommodate growth and development. Any time a
piece of land is divided into two or more tracts, the process is called
subdivision and the resulting tracts are in that subdivision. In reality the
process of creating a subdivision involves more than just dividing the land. It
also usually means the extension of infrastructure.
1.1.8  Plats.
   In most cases, the platting process performs the subdivision of land.
Platting generates a map showing the proposed legal areas (lots and blocks) to
be created, as well as the provisions for providing infrastructure to each lot.
The Final Plat is a legal document that is filed with the County Clerk for
public record. Among other things, the plat demonstrates that the owner of the
property is subdividing, that the boundary subdivision was performed by a
licensed and registered Texas surveyor, that the subdivider and any lienholders
are dedicating certain areas for public infrastructure use, that there are no
taxes owed on the land, and that various governmental entities have approved
the plat. Once filed with the County in the Plat records of Tarrant County, the
plat will be legally referred to by subdivision name, plat cabinet number and
slide number.
1.1.9  Plans.
   If any public improvements are to be extended to accommodate the subdivision
(either internal to the subdivision or external) then construction plans will
be required for the public improvements (water, sewer, streets, drainage,
etc.). In general, plans will include a cover sheet with index, general site
layout, plan and profile views of the improvements, required calculations and
quantity tables, details and standard details, and any other sheets required to
satisfactorily convey the location, adequacy and construction of the project.
The infrastructure plans shall be prepared by a Texas registered civil
engineer.
1.1.10  Agreements.
   In most instances, agreements will need to be signed in conjunction with the
final plat and plan approval. These agreements cover the work to be performed
and paid by the developer, any participation by the City (and why), other
covenants, and bonds or surety to assure completion and final payment for the
project.
1.1.11  Development and Building Additional Information.
   Additional summary information regarding specific items is given on the
following pages. (The following codes are used here: S = Staff review, PZ =
Meetings and action by P&Z, PH = Public hearings, CC = Meetings and action by
City Council, BOA = Meetings and action by BOA, P = permits or fees required, I
= Inspections required.)
1.2  Overview
1.2.1  Purpose.
   The Town of Lakeside Planning and Zoning Commission (hereafter referred to
as “P&Z”) has performed a careful study and formulated the rules and
regulations as set forth herein. The P&Z studied the existing local conditions
and the desirable features of modern subdivision planning principles as
followed by other progressive cities in this state and this general region. It
is not the desire, nor the intent, of the City Council or the P&Z to regiment
the design of subdivisions of property in the city and its environs, but rather
to recommend the utilization, to the fullest possible extent, of good, sound,
modern subdivision planning principles. It is intended that as much freedom as
possible be allowed the individual owners and subdividers in the design and
ultimate development of the new subdivisions so that they will:
   (1)   Contribute to the community new residential neighborhoods and
commercial areas with individuality and character,
   (2)   Provide for sufficient and adequate major and secondary traffic
thoroughfares, public utilities, parks and playgrounds, and
   (3)   Meet the provisions of the zoning ordinance, which is designed and
intended to stabilize and protect the established pattern of the best land
usage of all property within the city as it grows.
1.2.2  Applicability of Chapter.
   A person desiring to sell off a portion (or portions) of a tract of land
shall not do so until the land has been properly subdivided and recorded. Such
subdivision shall be done by formal plat, unless:
   1.   The land in question is and will remain in use for agricultural
purposes only, and
   2.   No portion is less than five (5) acres, and
   3.   The division does not require the extension or development of roadway,
public infrastructure or easements.
   To affect a plat, the owner thereof (or his legally authorized agent) shall
apply in writing to the City for approval of such land division following the
procedures described herein. The city building inspector shall not grant a
request for the erection of a structure until the plat process is completed.
1.2.3  Definitions.
   Access - Frontage to an approved public street or roadway.
   Agricultural Land - Land used exclusively for agricultural use and which
carries a valid taxing agricultural exemption.
   Alley - A minor public right-of-way, to provide auxiliary access to the back
of lots and not intended to provide the primary means of access to such lots.
   Amending Plat - A plat intended to correct minor errors only as allowed by
Texas Local Government Code 212.016. Does not require the approval of all
property owners. Such amendments (corrections) shall meet the criteria
established herein. The City Council may delegate and designate a staff member
to approve such plats.
   Applicant - The owner(s) of land, or legally designated representative of
the owner(s), desiring to subdivide land. As used herein, the terms “owner”,
“developer”, or “subdivider” shall all mean the applicant.
   Approved - Having approval of the appropriate authorities of the City as
defined herein.
   Block - Large section of land bounded by streets, property outside of the
subdivision or natural features. Blocks are subdivided into buildable “lots”.
Blocks are uniquely numbered on the plat.
   Building Setback Line - The line within a lot/tract defining the minimum
distance between a building and the adjacent property line as provided in the
Zoning Ordinance. Applicable to plats within the City Limits.
   City - The Town of Lakeside, Texas.
   City Council - The governing body of the City and the authority responsible
for the final approval of Final Plats and Replats (except minor (re)plats and
some amending plats).
   City Engineer - Engineer hired or appointed by the City to perform city
engineering functions, including the review of plats.
   Comprehensive Plan - The state mandated plan created and periodically
updated by the City for the promotion of orderly and planned growth/expansion.
The Comprehensive Plan includes the Thoroughfare plan, Water and Sewer Master
plans, Park Plans and other long-range plans.
   Cul-de-sac - A street having but one outlet to another street, and
terminated on the opposite end by a vehicular turnaround.
   Dedication - A gift or donation of property or interest in property by the
owner to the public.
   Easement - Land owned by the specific property owner but granted for a the
[sic] allowance of a specific use to the City, public or utility. The lot owner
is allowed to utilize such land “at risk”, meaning that any permanent
improvements placed on the easement by the land owner may be removed by the
easement holder. The easements are granted by legal document. When granted as a
part of the platting process, notations on the plat make the conveyance.
   Engineer - A person duly authorized to practice the profession of
engineering (P.E.) in the State of Texas, as stipulated by the current
amendments of the Texas Engineering Registration Act. If the total value of all
infrastructure which is to be public, or which is to be connected to public
infrastructure, exceeds $8,000 in gross value, the design of such
infrastructure by an appropriate engineer(s) for the particular specialties
involved is required. If the value of the gross improvements is unknown, or is
questionable, then an engineering design will also be required. In addition,
certain improvements, regardless of value, may require appropriate engineering
design.
   Extraterritorial Jurisdiction (ETJ) - The ETJ is the area within one-half
mile of the exterior of the existing Town of Lakeside City Limits. The City has
Subdivision jurisdiction within the ETJ but not Zoning jurisdiction. Plats in
the ETJ also require secondary approval by the County Commissioners Court.
   Final Plat - The official permanent record of the division of land, approved
by the appropriate bodies and recorded in the Plat Records of Tarrant County in
compliance with the requirements of this ordinance and State law.
   Infrastructure - Facilities needed to sustain buildable land. Infrastructure
includes, but is not limited to, streets, water, sewer, parks, other utilities,
and public facilities.
   Lot - An undivided tract or parcel of land having frontage on a public
street or private access easement or private drive and which is, or may be,
offered for sale, conveyance, transfer or improvement which is designated as a
distinct and separate tract and which is identified by a tract or lot number or
symbol in a duly approved subdivision plat which has been properly filed of
record[.]
   Minor (Re)Plat (Also known as an “Administrative (Re)Plat” or “Short Form
(Re)Plat”) - A plat allowed by Texas Local Government Code 212.0065. For such
plats the Council has authorized City Staff to affect without the need for
approval by P&Z or City Council so long as the following conditions shall be
met:
      1.   Involves less than four (4) residential lots, and
      2.   Involves less than five (5) total acres, and
      3.   Comprises the whole area to be platted (i.e., cannot be phased),
unless the area is a replat, and
      4.   Be applied for, and agreed to, by all affected property owners, and
      5.   Requires no additional public improvements, including access, and
      6.   Resulting lots meet the requirements of established City criteria.
If all of these conditions cannot be met, then the (re)plat must go through the
normal platting procedure.
   Owner - The person, or other entity, having legal ownership of real property
and is ultimately responsible for platting.
   Planner - The City employee or representative in charge of the planning
function for the City and assists with the implementation and enforcement of
the subdivision, zoning, and other growth-related ordinances.
   Planning and Zoning Commission (P&Z) - The Planning and Zoning Commission
(P&Z) of the City that acts as a recommending body to the City Council. The P&Z
is responsible for recommending subdivision and zoning ordinance changes to the
City Council and to screen applications to be sure that they meet the
established ordinances before going to City Council for approval. Such
authority is stipulated in the Local Government Code and other Texas Statutes.
The P&Z shall be the final judge in all cases regarding the application of the
rules and regulations of this ordinance. Officers of the P&Z will always freely
give advice and cooperation. (Compare to BOA.)
   Plat Administrator - The person designated by the City to receive and
process submissions made pursuant to this Ordinance and to enforce the terms
thereof. This is typically the Town Administrator for Lakeside.
   Plat Revision (or Replat) - A revision of existing platted and approved lot
lines for the purpose of relocating one or more lot lines between one or more
adjacent lots when the owner or owners of such lots join in the application for
revision.
   Preliminary Plat - A working document normally precedent to a final plat,
containing all planning factors deemed necessary by this Ordinance, or by the
platting authority, to determine the appropriate subdivision of land and the
requirements for extension of utilities, roadways, and other public
improvements.
   Right-of-Way - Land conveyed by plat, or other legal instrument, to the
public ownership and use for roadways, utilities and other public improvements.
Land dedicated as right-of-way shall be owned by the City, whereas land
dedicated by easement is owned by the individual landowner with a right of use
given to the City.
   Shall, May - The word “shall” is always mandatory. The word “may” is merely
“permissive”.
   Subdivider - Any owner, equitable owner, or authorized agent thereof,
dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision.
   Subdivision (noun) - A tract or parcel of land that has been divided into
two or more pieces for sale or development which has been properly platted,
approved and filed and for which required public rights-of-way, easements and
parcels have been dedicated and public improvements (streets, drainage, water,
sewer, etc.) installed.
   Subdivision (verb) - The act of dividing any tract or parcel of land located
all, or in part, in the City limits or extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ) of
the City into two (2) or more parts as described herein.
   Surveyor - Any person currently certified as a Registered Public Land
Surveyor (R.P.L.S.), or approved equal, by the Texas Board of Land Surveying.
All legal boundaries, metes and bounds descriptions, and existing topography
shown on plats must be surveyed, drawn and sealed by an appropriate surveyor.
   Vacating Plat - A plat used to rescind or make invalid a prior plat. Must
conform to the criteria described herein.
   BOA - The Board of Adjustment (BOA) is the judicial branch of the City with
regards to zoning issues. Items which do not comply with zoning criteria can be
appealed to the (BOA). Any appeal of a BOA decision must go to District Court.
   Zoning - Regulations defined by separate ordinance designed to
      (1)   lessen congestion in the streets,
      (2)   secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers
      (3)   promote health and general welfare,
      (4)   provide adequate light and air,
      (5)   prevent the overcrowding of land,
      (6)   avoid undue concentration of population, and
      (7)   facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewers,
schools, parks and other public requirements.
1.2.4  Fees.
 
Preliminary Plat $300*
Final Plat       $350*
Replat, Regular  $250*
Replat, Minor    $250*
Amending Plat    $250*
Vacating Plat    $250*
*The applicant is additionally responsible for payment of legal and
engineering fees incurred by the City in connection with the processing of the
application.
 
1.2.5  Timetables.
   At the time of the writing of this ordinance, the P&Z of the Town of
Lakeside meet on the third Monday of each month. The City Council meets on the
second Thursday of each month. (Such dates are subject to change by the City
Council and need to be verified by the plat applicant.) Plat submissions must
be filed at least 21 days prior to the relevant P&Z or Council meeting to allow
adequate advertising of such agenda items and public notice of any related
public hearings.

1.2.7  Subdivider’s Checklist.
   For the convenience of the Subdivider, checklists have been included in the
Appendices to these rules and regulations to assist in making sure all aspects
of the plats and plans have been attended to prior to submittal to the City for
formal approval.
1.3  Platting Process
1.3.1  Plat Consultation.
   It is required that each owner or subdivider of land first confer with the
Town of Lakeside Plat Administrator before preparing the preliminary plat of
the proposed subdivision and secure a copy of the rules and regulations
governing subdivisions and plats. This is so that they may become thoroughly
familiar with subdivision requirements and policies of the City. Once the owner
or subdivider has formulated a definitive concept plan, a meeting will be set
up with various members of city staff (and possibly utility officials, TxDOT
officials and up to 2 P&Z members) to review the concept and provide input
prior to the creation of a formal preliminary plat (or final plat, in those
instances where a preliminary is not required).
1.3.2  Filing with the City and County.
   A preliminary plat, final plat or replat shall not be considered “Filed”"
with the City until ALL of the following have successfully transpired:
 
                               The Subdivider shall begin the process
                               by scheduling a meeting with the City
                               Staff members responsible for review.
                               Such meeting shall be scheduled with the
                               Town Secretary, who will then be
                               responsible for coordinating a time with
                               the Subdivider, other City review staff,
Plat Consultation              utility companies, TxDOT, P&Z members
                               (up to 2), and others, as needed.
                               Subdivider shall bring any deeds, maps,
                               preliminary plans and design ideas for
                               water, sewer, drainage, streets, etc. to
                               the meeting. The Plat Administrator and
                               staff will also go over the subdivision
                               and building processes and requirements
                               with the Subdivider.
                               Plats (and Plans if a final Plat) have
                               been reviewed by City Staff and City
Staff Review                   Engineer and checked for accuracy and
                               completeness. Staff will generate
                               comments and markups.
Corrections Made               Subdivider has completed corrections
                               noted by City Staff and City Engineer.
                               Subdivider has provided the Plat
                               Administrator with any auxiliary
Supporting Documents Filed     paperwork or certifications required
                               including project plans for the public
                               improvements.
City Fees Paid                 The appropriate plat fees have been paid
                               to the City.
                               For final plats, any required

                               certifications (except for city staff

                               plats cannot be accepted for P&Z or
                               Council action.
 
   Once properly filed with the City, the City Council has 30 days in which to
take action on a Final Plat. Actions may include approval, denial, or mutually
agreed delays to accommodate requested revisions.
   The City shall file final, minor, amending or vacating plats with the County
Clerk after formal City approval and acceptance. The County Clerk shall assign
volume, page and plat cabinet recording information to make the plat legally
binding.
SECTION 2 - PLATTING
2.1  General Plat Information
2.1.1  Conformance of Plat Approval Application.
   The application of the Applicant for plat approval shall conform to the
specifications outlined in this ordinance.
2.1.2  Flooding.
   Land subject to flooding, as designated in a FEMA 100-year floodplain, shall
not be platted for residential occupancy (unless the floodplain is
appropriately modified by the applicant), nor shall it be platted for such
other uses as may increase danger to health, life or property or aggravate the
flood hazard. A Flood Hazard Statement meeting the requirements of the FIA is
required on the plat. (See Flood Hazard Block in the appendices.)
   Such land within the plat may be set aside for such uses that will not be
endangered by periodical or occasional inundation, or that will not produce
unsatisfactory living conditions.
2.1.3  Rights-of-Way and Easements.
   All public improvements (such as streets, utilities, parks or major drainage
conveyance areas) shall be installed in either right-of-ways or easements owned
by or conveyed to the City. Each lot within a subdivision shall abut right-of-
ways and easement adequate to serve the lot. As a minimum, all lots shall have
a ten (10) foot general utility easement along the front and back lot lines and
any side that is adjacent to a street. All other side lot lines shall have a
five (5) foot general utility easement on each side of the common lot line (ten
(10) feet total). Easements shall be larger when special conditions warrant.
All natural drainageways shall be in a drainage easement up to the 100-year
flood return elevation. Any drainage piping that is to be dedicated and
maintained by the City (i.e., serves more than one lot) shall be in an easement
with a minimum width of the structure (i.e., pipe diameter or box width) plus
twelve (12) feet (i.e., a 36-inch diameter pipe would require a minimum of
fifteen (15) feet of easement width). Each lot of a subdivision shall abut a
public street in dedicated right-of-way of the width specified for the
appropriate street classification in section 3.6. Where possible, sewers shall
be placed in the general utility easements along the periphery of lots. In
instances where the design conditions do not allow such placement, the sewer
shall be placed in an additional easement that is minimum of ten (10) feet
wide. All other parks and public places shall be dedicated to the City as
either right-of-way or lots. City public buildings and parking shall be on
dedicated public property or other property owned by the City.
   In areas where multiple lots will share a driveway or fire lane, such areas
shall be included in a dedicated access easement to the City, and any
additional needed cross access agreements among the multi-tenant owners, shall
be required to be filed with the plat.
2.1.4  Wetlands.
   Certain areas of property that stay wet and have certain flora and fauna, as
well as certain designated streams, are considered wetlands and are therefore
"waters of the U.S.". Development of these areas must be approved and permitted
through the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Failure to acquire such approval and
permit can lead to fines levied against the property owner. Attempting to plat
such areas for incompatible uses or improvements can be grounds for plat
denial.
2.1.5  Erosion Control.
   The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Texas Natural
Resource Conservation Commission (TCEQ) have regulations restricting the amount
of soil and other materials (erosion) that can be carried unintentionally from
a project site. Such regulations restrict the amount of erosion materials that
can wash onto neighboring property, wash into drainage facilities and/or be
dropped by vehicles onto roadways. As such, property owners are required to
obtain an erosion control permit by submitting a stormwater pollution
protection plan (SWPPP). The permit requires mechanical measures to prevent the
various types of erosion pollution.
2.1.6  Antiquities.
   Property owners should also be aware that the Texas Historical Commission
(among others) monitors development that may affect historical sites or
antiquities. It is up to the property owner to be sure such regulations are
complied with.
2.1.7  Other Regulations.
   The items above denote a number of the most common state and federal
regulations encountered by developers. The list is by no means exhaustive and
property owners and contractors shall be required to follow all relevant
regulations.
2.1.8  Utility Installation.
   a.   Definitions. The following terms, as used in this section, shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this subsection:
      Utility means a company providing electrical, telephone, cable
television, or cable- or wire-based data transmission services within the City.
      Transmission line means an electrical line operated at a nominal voltage
of 60,000 volts or higher that brings electricity from a generating plant to an
electrical substation.
      Feeder line means an electrical line that emanates from an electrical
substation or hub for distribution throughout a local area.
      Lateral line means an electrical line that emanates from a feeder line
and is used for distribution to smaller areas of consumers, and is usually
connected to a feeder line through a sectionalizing device such as a fuse or
disconnection switch.
      Service line means an electrical line which, through a transformer,
supplies electricity to a customer’s service entrance.
   b.   Undergrounding required.
      (1)   All electric lateral and service lines throughout the interior of
new residential subdivisions shall be placed underground and in dedicated
easements. This provision does not require the underground installation of
transmission lines or of feeder lines placed along the perimeter of a
subdivision.
      (2)   Wherever electric lateral and service lines are required to be
placed underground, lines carrying telephone service, data transmission, cable
television, and street lighting shall also be placed underground.
      (3)   All electrical, telephone, data transmission, or cable television
support equipment necessary for underground installation, including
transformers, amplifiers, switching devices, etc., shall be pedestal- or pad-
mounted, or shall placed underground.
   c.   Owner to bear cost.
      (1)   The owner of property for which this section requires utility
facilities to be placed underground shall arrange to reimburse the utility
company for the difference in cost between the installation of such service and
the installation of equivalent overhead service in accordance with the
provisions of the utility's tariff, if any.
      (2)   No utility shall be required to begin construction of underground
facilities unless and until the owner has made arrangements satisfactory to the
utility company for the payment of the difference between the cost of overhead
facilities and underground facilities.
   d.   Exceptions to undergrounding requirement.
      (1)   Temporary service during construction may be provided by overhead
utility lines and facilities prior to activation of the underground service.
Following activation of the underground permanent service, the temporary
overhead service shall be removed within 45 days.
      (2)   Nothing in this section 2.1.8 shall be construed to require any
existing overhead facilities to be placed underground or to prohibit the
upgrading, reconstruction or reconductoring of any existing overhead facilities
with overhead construction.
   e.   Variances. In special or unique circumstances or to avoid undue
hardship, the City Council, after receiving the recommendation of the Planning
and Zoning Commission, may authorize a variance to the underground utilities
requirements of this section.
2.1.9  Public Improvements.
   All land subdividers and developers shall on all new subdivisions of land in
the City, or its ETJ, adhere to and be governed by the policies that are
specified in this ordinance for the provision, construction and placement of
street improvements, drainage structures, alleys or easements, utilities and
parks and playgrounds.
   The developer shall be required to install or furnish all drainage
facilities, water lines, sewer lines, street signs, electrical lines, gas
lines, easements and other public facilities required for the development of
the platted area. There will be no participation by the City in improvements
cost unless such is determined by the City.
2.1.10  Parks, Schools, and Playgrounds.
   Sites suitable for parks, schools, playgrounds or other public usage, as
required by the City, should be carefully considered in collaboration with the
P&Z and so indicated upon the Preliminary Plat. This is done so that these
sites can be checked for conformity with the recommended locations indicated in
the Comprehensive Plan and so that these sites should be in conformity with the
general requirements of the City and in keeping with modern planning
principles. They shall be of adequate size as recommended by the P&Z and as may
be required by the City under its policies and specifications. The P&Z may
require the owner or subdivider to obtain a letter from the appropriate
independent school district stating that provisions for the site of future
schools, if such be required, are adequate. If a school site is not required,
the letter is to so state.
2.1.11  Other Monetary Obligations.
   No subdivision plat shall be finally considered by the City Council unless
and until all taxes, assessments, charges and other monetary obligations due
the Town of Lakeside and outstanding with respect to the property which is the
subject of the subdivision application shall be paid current, including all
penalties, interest and other charges due with respect to same.
   2.2  Lots and Blocks.
2.2.1  Block Lengths.
   Block lengths, generally, should not exceed one thousand (1,000) feet in
length. Should blocks exceed this length, there shall be provided, near the
center of the block, a utility or pedestrian easement or walk at least ten (10)
feet in width.
2.2.2  Lot Dimensions.
   The minimum dimensions of lots in subdivisions shall be established based on
zoning requirements for areas inside the City limits. Such dimensions shall be
given in the latest issue of the Zoning Ordinance. Corner lots shall be
increased in size as necessary to permit any structure placed thereupon to
conform to the building line of each street in accordance with the Zoning
Ordinance requirements. Lots which have frontage on more than two streets are
undesirable and will not be allowed where it possible to avoid them. In
general, side lot lines shall be at right angles or radial to street lines.
2.2.3  Building Setback Lines.
   Where applicable, building setback lines shall be shown on all lots.
   2.3  Preliminary Plats
2.3.1  Plat Information.
   The Preliminary Plat shall include or be accompanied by the following
information. The checklist shown in the appendix should be used in conjunction
with the following list to be sure this information has been completely
addressed.

2.3.2  Effect of Approval.
   It is to be understood that the approval of the Preliminary Plat by the P&Z
and the City Council does not constitute official acceptance of the proposed
subdivision by the City, but does constitute an authorization to begin and
proceed with the preparation of the Final Plat. Construction work on the
proposed subdivision shall not begin until the Final Plat has been approved and
accepted in an official action by the P&Z and the City Council and the
instrument recorded in the office of the County Clerk.
2.3.3  Expiration of Plat.
   Approval of the preliminary plat expires at the end of nine (9) months after
the approval date. For a phased subdivision, any part of the preliminary plat
which has not been final platted shall expire after one year from the
completion of the previous phase if a new phase is not started.
2.4  Final Plats
2.4.1  Plat Submission.
   The submittal must include the items and number of copies stipulated herein.
The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn on a scale of 1" = 100'. All
figures and letters shown thereon shall be plain, distinct and of sufficient
size that they can be easily read. Should more than one sheet be required for
the layout, there shall be included a key map showing the entire subdivision,
drawn at a smaller scale, with block numbers and street names. This key map is
to be included upon the first sheet or presented separately as a cover sheet
the same size as the large-scale sheet.

2.4.3  Plat Approval.
   The following conditions shall be met for plat approval:
 
                                   The developer, prior to final approval of a
                                   plat, shall take bids on all required
                                   improvements and installations and
                                   tabulations to the city along with bids of
                                   his choice. Each bid shall be accompanied
Bid Project and execute developer  by a performance bond, payment bond and two
agreement and bonds with the City. (2) year maintenance bond. The developer
                                   shall furnish the City a developer
                                   agreement and escrow with the city a cash
                                   deposit to cover all contract cost plus 0.2
                                   (2/10%) percent of total cost for
                                   inspection fees.
                                   The City shall record the plat in the
File Plat with County              office of the County Clerk within three
                                   weeks of all approval conditions being met.
 
   No Building Permits shall be issued for any lot in the subdivision, or any
lots sold, until the following condition is complied with. The only exception
shall be that residential home builders can start “model homes” which are not
for immediate sale or occupancy and are used solely for demonstration and
advertising at the entrance to the subdivision once sufficient access and
utilities have been installed in that area.
 
                                   The owners of the subdivision shall file
                                   with the P&Z, within two (2) months after
Certify Satisfactory Completion of the date of construction completion, a
Improvements                       certificate stating that the improvements as
                                   specified and required by the city have been
                                   completed in accordance with the city’s
                                   standards and specifications.
 
2.4.4  Approval by Sections (Phases).
   An owner or developer, at his option, may obtain final approval of a portion
or section of a subdivision, provided he meets all the requirements of this
ordinance in the same manner as is required for a complete subdivision. Any
phasing must be shown on the Preliminary Plat. Any portion of a final plat that
developed in sections or phases must correspond to the sections or phases on
the Preliminary Plat. In the event the developer chooses to submit a final plat
that does not agree with the approved phasing plan contained on an approved
preliminary plat, the preliminary plat must be resubmitted with amended phasing
indicated. In the event a subdivision and the final plat thereof is approved by
the City Council in sections, each Final Plat of each section is to carry the
name of the entire subdivision, but is to be distinguished from each other
section by a distinguishing letter, number or subtitle designating the Phase.
Block numbers shall run consecutively throughout the entire subdivision, even
though such subdivision may be finally approved in sections.
2.4.5  Refusal of Approval for Inadequate Infrastructure.
   The P&Z may refuse to approve a plat whenever it is evident that adequate
infrastructure (roadways and utilities) cannot be supplied within a reasonable
time.
2.5  Replats
2.5.1  Replats.
   Except for Minor Replats, any replatting of subdivision lots requires
submittal, review and approval of the P&Z and the City Council. However, a
preliminary plat is not required for replats and the replat must follow the
guidelines of a final plat. All replats must conform to Texas Local Government
Code Sections 212.014 and 212.015 including concurrence of all affected
landowners and proper public hearings. Replats cannot be used to amend or
remove any covenants or restrictions.
2.5.2  Minor Replats.
   State law allows for a minor (administrative) replat that City Staff can
affect without the need for reapproval by P&Z or City Council. To be handled as
a minor replat, the plat must meet all of the guidelines described above in the
definition of "Minor Replat". This plat is generally used to correct for
physical encroachments in which reallocation of property by the affected
landowners is preferred over the correction of the physical feature.
2.6  Amending Plats
2.6.1  Plat Corrections.
   Minor errors in plats may be corrected by the use of an Amending Plat.
Amending plats shall only be used to make corrections in accordance with the
specific conditions stipulated in Texas Local Government Code 212.016. Amending
Plats can be considered directly by City Council (or their staff designee, if
so chosen) without review by the P&Z.
   Any corrections not falling under the criteria of LGC 212.016 will require
full resubmittal of the plat and will be treated as a replat.
2.7  Vacating Plats
2.7.1  Plat Vacations.
   A plat may be vacated (be rescinded or made invalid) in the manner described
by Texas Local Government Code 212.013. To be vacated, the plat must indicate
that it is being vacated and be signed and approved by all landowners involved.
City approval and plat recording shall be the same as the original plat. The
vacation must include all of the land involved in the original platting.
SECTION 3 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS (PLANS)
3.1  General
3.1.1  General.
   The owner or subdivider of property shall observe the general requirements
and principles of land subdivision and street layout contained herein.
Improvements shall comply with all applicable state and federal laws, as well
as city ordinances. Where not explicitly governed herein, infrastructure
designs shall comply with the guidelines of the City Engineer and standard
engineering practices in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, taking into account the
guidelines of national testing and guideline groups (AWWA, NSF, etc.).
3.1.2  Variations and Modifications.
   Variations and modifications of the general requirements as outlined herein
may be made by the P&Z when, in its judgment, special or peculiar factors and
conditions warrant such variations and the variations do not affect the general
application or spirit of the rules and regulations.
3.1.3  North Central Texas Council of Government Specifications.
   Plans and specifications for contract documents, materials and construction
of public improvements shall generally adhere to the items in the Standard
Specifications for Public Works Construction, latest revision as published by
the North Central Texas Council of Governments (hereinafter referred to as
NCTCOG Specs) or as specified and amended by the design engineer. Copies of the
NCTCOG Specs may be purchased from the North Central Texas Council of
Governments, 616 Six Flags Drive, Suite 200, (P.O. Box 5888), Arlington, Texas
76055-5888. NCTCOG can be contacted at 817-640-3300.
3.1.4  Subdivider/Developer Agreements.
   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider/developer to provide, at
their own cost, proper access and utilities to each lot in the subdivision as
set forth herein. In certain cases, the subdivider/developer may elect to
provide additional amenities beyond that which are required by the City. In
other cases, the City may elect to participate in infrastructure upsizing to
provide service or potential service to more than the affected subdivision. In
all cases where streets, utilities or other public improvements are concerned,
a written agreement between the subdivider/developer and the City will be
required. Such agreement shall delineate the payments to be made by the
respective parties, the surety that such work will be performed and the
provisions for the perpetual maintenance of such improvements.
3.1.5  Comprehensive Plan.
   Any platted subdivision shall adhere and incorporate the relevant aspects of
the City’s Comprehensive Plan in effect prior to the final approval of the
Final Plat. These shall include, but shall not be limited to, thoroughfares,
main utility transmission lines, etc. Such items on the Comprehensive Plan are
necessary for the orderly growth of the City as a whole.
3.1.6  Subdivider Plan Requirements.
   The subdivider of each tract of land will be required to construct, at his
own expense, the water, sewer, streets, drainage and other infrastructure
improvements necessary to service the subdivision in accordance with the City’s
standards and specifications, including all engineering costs covering design,
layout and construction supervision. The subdivider, at his own expense, shall
include all fire hydrants, street signs, street markings, streetlights and
other necessary appurtenances to provide for a complete and functioning
project. Final plans for such improvements shall be submitted to the P&Z for
study by the City Engineer and approval recommendation. Plats, plans,
agreements and bonds must be approved by the City Council before any work is
started in the subdivision. Detailed construction plans, including the plan and
profile for each street, water line, sewer line, and storm drainage line shall
be filed with the submission of the final plat in the same number of copies as
required of the final subdivision plat. Where plats are presented for approval
that adjoin unplatted property, the owner and/or developer of the proposed
subdivision shall provide his pro rata share of the improvements cost of for
[sic] boundary streets or other joint facilities. Where the boundary streets
are not to be paved in their entire width abutting the proposed subdivision,
the owner and/or developer shall deposit funds into escrow with the City. Each
street installation project will be considered by the City upon the individual
merits of each project prior to construction.
   As a minimum, each plan set shall be on 24" x 34" blueline paper and include
the following items. Each sheet shall have an approved title block in the lower
right-hand corner (or along the right edge) and shall be sealed and signed by
the licensed design engineer.
SECTION INCLUDING
SECTION                 INCLUDING
                        Project title, location map, index, city officials,
Cover Sheet             date, design firm, seal and signature of design
                        engineer.
                        Copy of the final plat (unapproved plat to be included
Final Plat              for review, substituted with approved plat after plat
                        approval.)
Geometric Site Layout   Layout of the entire site with coordinate layout of
                        major control points and listing of all benchmarks used
                        Sheets showing horizontal and vertical geometry along

                        annotated on at least 100' stations with annotations

                        city projects.
 
3.2  Site Grading
3.2.1  General Design.
   Before any earthwork is performed on the subdivision, the developer shall
submit a site-grading plan showing the existing contours and the proposed
contours for the work. Contours shown shall be in either 1' or 2' vertical
intervals. The plan shall demonstrate that the work will not have any
appreciable change in the site drainage characteristics or shall show the site
modification and any mitigation measures necessary to accommodate the change.
In addition, the plan shall show that no grading will not adversely affect
adjacent property owners and will include temporary and permanent erosion
control measures. The plan shall also include State/Federal approvals for work
involving 404 wetlands and any other required State/Federal approvals that may
be applicable to the site. (See section on Drainage below.)
3.2.2  Finished Floors (Pad Sites).
   The site grading plan and all construction shall be such that building pads
for structures shall drain away at a minimum of 2% grade in all directions from
the structure for at least 50' from the edge of structure, unless proper walls,
ditches, or underground drainage systems are used to capture and convey 100-
year runoff away from the building. In any area in which localized building
flooding appears to be a concern, the applicant shall set a minimum finish
floor elevation and show such on the grading plans.
3.2.3  Amenities.
   Where possible, the applicant is encouraged to preserve trees and unique
natural features in the site grading area.
3.3  Drainage
3.3.1  General Design.
   The old axiom that “water runs downhill” is definitely true. Since
modifications to existing property normally tend to interfere with the soil’s
ability to absorb rainfall, development generally causes increased runoff from
the affected property. As such, rules and laws have been established to protect
downstream property owners from excessive increases in runoff flows across
their property. For this reason, care must be taken to calculate and mitigate
any significant increases in flow leaving the property. Typically, this is done
by several methods such as piping the flows directly to a natural conduit
capable of conveying the increased runoff without detriment to others or by
capturing the excess runoff and slowly releasing it so that it leaves at a rate
not exceeding the predevelopment rate.
   In addition, care must be taken not to flood streets or buildable property
within the proposed subdivision itself.
3.3.2  EPA Stormwater Permit.
   An EPA Stormwater permit is required for all construction sites which are 5
acres or larger. The area requirement is based on the total development, not
just the portion currently under construction. In essence, this requirement is
for all subdivisions in which the Preliminary Plat (or Final Plat, if a
preliminary is not required) is 5 acres or more. No earthwork can take place on
an EPA permitted site (or a site eligible for an EPA permit) until a Stormwater
Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) has been developed and a Notice of Intent
(NOI) filed with the EPA. Further information may be obtained at www.epa.gov.
3.3.3  Design Methods.
   The determination of design discharge of storm drainage water shall be
accomplished in accordance with the following criteria:
      (1)   The Rational Method (Q = CIA) shall be used on small watersheds of
one thousand acres (1,000) acres or less.
      (2)   Unit hydrographic techniques shall be used for areas greater than
one thousand (1,000) acres.
   The City Engineer prior to the completion of calculations shall approve the
technique and data to be used for the determination of the design discharge. A
complete set of all detailed calculations must be submitted to the City
Engineer for approval prior to the completion of the plans for the drainage
system.
3.3.4  Design Frequencies, Intensities and Duration.
   For all non-critical streets, the 100-year return frequency storm runoff can
be contained within the street right-of-way. Non-critical streets are streets
that are not thoroughfares. All bridges, culverts, underpasses, and open
ditches shall be designed for a 100-year return frequency storm based on
ultimate upstream development conditions. All piped storm drainage shall be
designed such that at least one lane of any thoroughfare is open during a 100-
year event, and such that any overflow due to a 100-year event storm is
contained within the street right-of-way for non-thoroughfare streets or within
the easement or right-of-way of non-street areas.
   The intensity and duration of the rainfall shall be based on the Texas
Department of Transportation formula and TxDOT coefficients for Tarrant County
for areas less than 1000 acres. Technical Paper No. 40 of the Weather Bureau of
the United States Department of Commerce, or other methods approved by the City
Engineer, shall be used for larger areas. Flow in streams which have been
studied by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and which have been studied and
mapped by FEMA, shall use Corps data as an initial basis.
3.3.5  Sizes and Capacities.
   Drainage pipes shall be designed such that the hydraulic grade line (HGL) is
continually maintained at least 18" below the top of curb, or below street
subgrade, whichever is lower.
   Plans shall show all hydraulic calculations, including structure losses, and
the HGL shall be plotted on all profiles. In no case shall drainage pipes be
less than 18" inside diameter.
3.3.6  Time of Concentration.
   The time of concentration is defined as the longest time that will be
required for a drop of water to flow from the upper limit of the drainage area
to the point of concentration.
   The minimum times of concentration are shown below:
 
Parks and permanent open areas       20 minutes
Single-Family and Duplex residential 10 minutes
Multifamily, Business and Industrial 10 minutes
 
   In cases where it is evident that the actual time of concentration is more
than that indicated above, the longer time of concentration should be used.
3.3.7  Runoff Coefficients.
   The coefficient of runoff to be used in the calculations shall be as
follows:
 
Streets                               0.95
Industrial areas                      0.95
Business areas                        0.90
Multifamily                           0.65
Residential areas (less than 2 acres) 0.50
Residential areas (2 acres or more)   0.40
Park areas and permanent open space   0.35
 
   The coefficient of runoff for undeveloped land shall be the appropriate
coefficient for the ultimate land development as shown on the Future Land Use
Map of the Comprehensive Plan.
3.3.8  Discharges and Velocities.
   Under full pipe design conditions, pipe flows shall not be less than 2 feet
per second or greater than 10 feet per second. Velocities below 2 fps tend to
leave mud and other debris lodged in pipes. Velocities over 10 fps tend to
erode the inside of pipes and cause erosion problems at the outfall. Pipe
discharges shall not be greater than the capacity of the natural system at the
outflow when added to the flows already reaching the natural system for the
design storm event.
3.3.9  Pipe Materials.
   All storm drainage facilities within street rights-of-ways shall be
constructed of reinforced concrete pipe and reinforced concrete structures.
Structures outside of right-of-way areas may use other types of interior smooth
wall pipes in special cases that are approved by the City Engineer and in which
the design engineer demonstrates that such facilities can accommodate the
expected flows, scour and loadings.
   The capacity of pipes shall be calculated by Manning’s formula, or other
method approved by the City Engineer.
3.3.10  Inlets.
   Inlets may be cast-in-place or precast. Grate inlets may be allowed on
private property or off-site ditches. No grates shall be allowed in street
sections. Inlets shall be properly protected during construction so as not to
allow debris and sedimentation to enter the inlet. As a minimum, curb inlets
must be designed to capture at least 1 cfs per linear foot of opening.
3.3.11  Outflow Structures.
   Outflow structures shall be designed to protect the ends of storm piping and
culverts, prevent downstream erosion (i.e. dissipate outflow energy), and
protect any adjacent streets or structures.
3.3.12  Open Channel Flow.
   Open ditches may be used to carry surface runoff in areas in which enough
width is available to accommodate the required section. Capacity of ditches
shall be calculated by Manning’s formula, or other method approved by the City
Engineer. Ditches shall be constructed of sufficient size to carry the intended
runoff. The side slopes of all ditches shall be 3H:1V or flatter.
3.3.13  Off-site Drainage.
   a.   The owner or developer of property to be developed shall be responsible
for all storm drainage flowing on his property. This responsibility includes
the drainage directed to that property by prior development as well as drainage
naturally flowing through the property by reason of topography.
   b.   Adequate consideration shall be given by the owner in the development
of property to determine how the discharge leaving the proposed development
will affect downstream property.
   c.   In all new development where stormwater runoff has been collected or
concentrated, it shall not be permitted to drain onto adjacent property except
in existing creeks, channels or storm sewer unless proper drainage easements or
notarized letters of permission from the affected property owners are provided.
   d.   The subdivider shall pay for the cost of all drainage improvements
required for the development of his subdivision, including any necessary off-
site channels or storm sewers and acquisition of the required easements with
the following exception: If the owner is unable to acquire the necessary off-
site easements, he shall provide the City with documentation of his efforts,
including evidence of a reasonable offer made to the affected property owners.
Should the City receive such a written request for assistance and the City
determines that the need for off-site easements is the only practical solution
to the problem, the City shall attempt to acquire these easements through
negotiations and, if necessary, condemnation. It shall be understood that
condemnation shall only be used as a condition of last resort. In any case, the
owner or developer shall pay all costs associated with the acquisition of these
easements.
Where it is anticipated that additional runoff incident to the development of
the subdivision will overload an existing downstream drainage facility, whether
natural or man-made, and result in hazardous conditions, the P&Z may withhold
approval of the subdivision until appropriate provision has been made to
accommodate the problem, and plans shall be provided which include all
necessary off-site improvements including storm systems, channel grading,
driveway adjustments, culvert improvements, etc.
3.3.14  Bridges and Culverts.
   Bridges or culverts shall be constructed at all street locations where flow
patterns cross the street and are not intercepted by an underground storm sewer
system or appropriate concrete valley gutter. (Note: Valley gutters on public
streets shall not be used to convey more than 10 cfs based on a 100-year
event.) Such bridges and culverts must accommodate the 100-year design flows
based on fully developed upstream conditions. Bridges and culverts must be
designed to accommodate the needed driving lanes for cross traffic along with
any safety end treatment, protective offsets, guardrail, signs and/or lighting.
3.3.15  Detention and Retention Ponds.
   All subdivisions and sites are required to install Detention/Retention ponds
if the post-construction 100-year design flow leaving the subdivision or site
at any concentrated point is increased more than 10 cfs from the predesigned
condition. Outlet structures shall be staged to prevent more than 10 cfs
difference at the 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 year flow levels. Outflow structures
should be well maintained and unobstructed. Provisions for maintenance shall be
included with plat or deed covenants. Except by special consideration, all
detention and retention ponds shall remain the property of the subdivider/
developer/homeowners association, and shall not be the direct responsibility of
the City. Retention ponds shall be protected to prevent drowning and water
stagnation (mosquitoes).
3.4  Water
3.4.1  General Design.
   Where existing water supplies are available, the developer shall extend the
existing system to serve the new subdivision and provide for lines for the
extension of the system beyond the subdivision. Where existing water supplies
are not available, the developer may install a complete water system to serve
his subdivision and dedicate such system to the City for operation, or he may
leave it to the purchaser of each lot to provide water from wells. In the event
that new wells are required (either public or private), their location and the
construction of all required water facilities shall conform to TCEQ rules and
current city ordinances (including sanitary control easements and verification
of groundwater supplies). In no event shall individual lot wells be drilled
closer than 150' to any portion of a sewer or septic system or any other
contamination source.
3.4.2  Impact Fees.
   The Town of Lakeside has not adopted impact fees.
3.4.3  Minimum Sizes.
   The size of lines to be installed shall be determined by the City's
Comprehensive Plan for water and the type of development to be served. Feeder
mains shall not be smaller than eight (8) inches and the system shall be
looped. Branch mains in commercial areas shall not be smaller than eight inches
(8") and branch mains in residential areas shall not be smaller than six inches
(6"). If indicated by the Comprehensive Plan or if a need is demonstrated by
the running of an approved electronic water model (KyPipe, CYBERNET, etc.),
mains shall be upsized accordingly.
3.4.4  Looped System.
   All water mains 8" and larger shall be looped. Smaller mains shall be
looped, if possible. Deadend mains must be approved by the City and shall have
provisions at the dead-end for flushing the line. Dead-end mains longer than
1200 feet shall not be allowed.
3.4.5  Materials.
   For sizes smaller than 16", PVC DR-18 pipe (class 150 or stronger)
conforming to AWWA standard C-900 shall be used. For larger pipes, polywrapped
ductile iron (class 150 or stronger) or concrete cylinder pipe shall be used.
   Asbestos Cement pipe, glued or threaded PVC (including schedules 20, 40, or
80) shall NOT be allowed for water mains or connections prior to the customer
water meter.
3.4.6  Minimum Cover.
   Lines 12" and smaller shall have a minimum cover of 42". Larger pipes shall
have a minimum cover of 60". All water lines shall have a tracing line located
1' above the top of pipe.
3.4.7  Horizontal Geometry.
   Water lines shall be placed in the northern and/or eastern parkways of the
street or in easements allowing the installation of water lines. Water lines
shall be placed a minimum of 10 feet from parallel sewer lines. At any location
where water and sewer lines will be closer than 10 feet, for any reason, TCEQ
rules for special pipe shall apply to both water and sewer lines.
3.4.8  Vertical Geometry.
   Water lines shall be placed so as to avoid mechanical bends. Minimum covers
as stipulated above shall be maintained. A one-foot (1') vertical separation
(outside of pipe to outside of pipe) between the water line and other utilities
shall be maintained at all crossings.
3.4.9  Valves.
   All mains shall contain a valve at least every 1000 feet. A valve shall be
installed on at least two legs of every main tee. A valve shall be placed near
the end of any dead-end main provided that at least one joint of pipe shall be
placed beyond the valve and anchored. This final joint shall also contain a
means of flushing the line. Valves deeper than 36" shall employ valve
extensions to within 36" of the ground surface. Valve nuts shall be covered
with three-piece adjustable cast iron box covers set to grade. All valves shall
be right-hand turning to close. Valves 12" and smaller shall be Mueller A-2370
Resilient Seat Gate Valves, or approved equal. Larger valves shall be Mueller
Line Seal III Butterfly valves, or approved equal.
3.4.10  Fire Hydrants and Fire Lanes.
   Fire Hydrants with valves shall be installed at each street intersection and
at a minimum of five hundred (500) feet spacing in any residential zoning and
three hundred (300) feet spacing in all other zones. Additional fire hydrants
shall be placed as necessary such that all ground portions of all buildings in
the subdivision can be reached with a normal 300-foot lay of fire hose. In most
instances, commercial buildings will be required to have fire suppression
systems and fire spigots in addition to the normal fire hydrants.
   Fire hydrants shall be Mueller, Waterous or other equal approved by the City
Engineer. All fire hydrants shall include a line valve between the fire hydrant
and the water main.
   Where possible, fire hydrants shall be located not further than 15' from a
street or fire lane. Fire lanes shall not be narrower than 20'. Blue pavement
reflectors, meeting the criteria of the fire department, shall be installed at
the center of the street(s) adjacent to each fire hydrant location.
3.4.11  Blocking.
   Fire hydrants, valves and pipe ends shall be blocked with unreinforced
concrete (at least 2500 psi) as shown in the City’s standard water details. If
blocking for a particular situation is not given in the City details, then the
NCTCOG details shall be used. In no instance shall rocks be in contact with the
pipe or fittings.
3.5  Sewer
3.5.1  General Design.
   The developer shall install a complete sewage collection system to serve the
subdivision. This requirement may be waived in areas in which sewer collection
is not currently available and it would be infeasible to connect to distant
collection facilities. In such cases, consideration will be given to individual
septic or aeration systems for each lot. However such systems must undergo
proper permitting, testing, and area restrictions.
3.5.2  Minimum Sizes.
   The size shall be determined by the City Comprehensive Plan and the type of
development to be served. Sufficient line sizes for the continuation of the
system to future developments shall be required. Lines smaller than 6" shall be
prohibited.
3.5.3  Materials.
   Sewer lines shall be SDR-35, ring-gasketed bell and spigot PVC pipe
conforming to ASTM Specifications D3034. Pipe shall be Johns-Manville, Cantex,
or approved equal.
3.5.4  Minimum Depths and Cover.
   Pipes shall be installed at a minimum of four and one-half (4-1/2) feet
below the lowest finished grade to be served for normal lots (up to 200-foot
lot depth). For larger lots, the line must be deeper such that any building
constructed can reach the line using a 2% slope on the lateral.
   In general, all sewer lines shall have a minimum of 4' of ground cover.
3.5.5  Horizontal Design.
   Sewer lines shall be at least 10 feet from parallel water lines. Where
possible, sewer lines shall be placed down the middle of the street. Otherwise,
lines shall be placed on the street side opposite the water line at an offset
directed by the City Engineer. Except for streets with centerline radii greater
than 1,000', all sewer sections shall be straight horizontally from manhole to
manhole.
3.5.6  Crossings.
   All sewer crossings shall conform to TCEQ published guidelines (See TCEQ
Section 290).
3.5.7  Bedding and Encasement.
   The pipe shall be properly embedded and cased depending on the pipe size,
depth of cover, and anticipated loads. Bedding shall be a noncompactable
granular material with the pipe contact points placed carefully to within 0.01'
of plan grade. Contact points for the pipe bell shall be scooped out so that
the pipe bearing rests on the main run of the pipe and not on the bell. Once
set to grade, bedding material shall be installed to the pipe spring line (mid-
pipe). An appropriate free-flowing material shall be used to fill the remainder
of the pipe section to a point at least 1' above the top of pipe. Properly
compacted select fill, as directed, shall be required for the remainder of the
backfilling operation.
3.5.8  Minimum and Maximum Grades.
Pipe Size, inches Minimum Grade, %(to provide at Maximum Grade, %(to prevent
(inside diameter) least 2 fps velocity)          more than 8 fps velocity)
Pipe Size, inches Minimum Grade, %(to provide at Maximum Grade, %(to prevent
(inside diameter) least 2 fps velocity)          more than 8 fps velocity)
6"                0.60%                          5.62%
8"                0.36%                          3.83%
10"               0.24%                          2.84%
12"               0.20%                          2.23%
15"               0.16%                          1.65%
18"               0.12%                          1.30%
See TCEQ rules for larger sizes.
 
   Plan grades shall not have vertical grade changes except at manholes.
Vertical curves shall not be allowed.
3.5.9  Manhole and Cleanout Requirements.
   Connected manholes shall not be separated by more than 500'. In addition, a
manhole shall be placed at every location where changes in pipe size, pipe
type, pipe direction, or intersection of other connecting pipes (other than
single service laterals) occurs. A terminal manhole at the far upstream end of
a line can be replaced by a cleanout if the cleanout is within 250' of the
downstream manhole. The following chart shall determine manhole inside
diameter.
 
Maximum Pipe Size Connected to Manhole  Inside Minimum Diameter of Manhole
(inch OD)                               (feet)
18" and less                            4.0
21" - 27"                               5.0
30" - 36"                               6.0
39" and greater                         As Directed by City Engineer
 
   Manholes in the floodplain, or in areas normally subject to runoff water
flows, shall have a waterproof seal in the top. Areas subject to known
vandalism shall have bolt-down lids.
3.5.10  Infiltration.
   System infiltration shall not be more than 200 gallons per inch of diameter
per mile of pipe per 24 hours. For example, 2 miles of 8" pipe cannot have more
than 3200 gallons of infiltration flow in a 24-hour period. Should federal or
state criteria be more stringent than this requirement, and then [sic] federal
or state criteria shall be used to calculate the infiltration limit.
3.5.11  Drop Manholes.
   Whenever the difference in elevation from the flowline of the highest inflow
pipe to the flowline of the exit pipe exceeds 2' in any manhole, a drop manhole
shall be installed. This manhole shall incorporate a vertical shoot of the same
diameter (or larger) as the high incoming pipe(s) to convey the sewage to a
point within 0.5' (6") of the outlet flowline. This is done to prevent
excessive splashing in the manhole in order to reduce noise and odor.
3.5.12  Service Laterals.
   Each building to be connected to the sewer main shall be connected via a
separate connection. No common services shall be allowed without approval of
the City Engineer. In the event that more than one building needs to flow to an
existing main in a common pipe, then the connecting pipe from the junction of
the two services to the existing main shall conform to all of the requirements
of sewer mains, including easements which shall be dedicated to the City after
approval. Services 6" or less in size can be connected by approved line taps
which do not obstruct any portion of the main. All lines larger than 6" shall
be connected directly to manholes. All services shall be sized according to the
Uniform Plumbing Code and shall be installed with the oversight and approval of
the City’s Building Inspector or Sewer System Manager. When sewers are placed
in, or along, street sections, laterals shall be extended to the right-of-way
line on both sides of the street prior to street construction.
3.6  Streets
3.6.1  General Design.
   Any owner of land, subdivider, his or their engineer, land planner or any
other person making a street layout for any parcel of land or subdivision shall
design the streets in accordance with accepted industry standards meeting at
least the following design standards.
3.6.2  TxDOT Controlled Highways.
   The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) is responsible for State and
Federal highways, several of which are within the Town of Lakeside and its ETJ.
TxDOT has approval jurisdiction for all streets and driveways that access these
highways. Such jurisdiction includes driveway access locations and sizes,
median openings and acceleration/deceleration lanes. It should also be noted
that Interstate 20 is a Federally “Controlled Access Interstate” and no access
shall be allowed except onto approved locations on frontage roads. Any time a
subdivision plat is adjacent to a TxDOT controlled roadway, TxDOT officials
will be involved in the reviews for the plat approval process. Should it be
deemed that the proposed development will have a detrimental impact on the
TxDOT highway, then additional studies or improvements may be required prior to
access to the TxDOT facility.
3.6.3  Traffic Impact Studies.
   Regardless of whether or not a subdivision is adjacent to a TxDOT highway,
the City may require a traffic impact study if it appears that the proposed
development will have a significant impact on the adjacent existing roadways.
In some cases, subdividers may be required to upgrade existing feeder roads in
order to adequately service their development.
3.6.4  Street Classifications.
   Streets shall be designed based on their classifications. Classifications
depend on the quantity and speed of expected traffic. Roadways requiring higher
through speeds or large volumes of traffic shall have higher classifications
and be designed to accommodate these conditions. Normally, the higher
classified streets affect more than one subdivision and must be coordinated
among a number of subdivisions. Such roadways are shown on the City’s
Comprehensive Plan and all affected areas being platted are required to conform
to this plan. In Lakeside, the following classifications shall be used:
CLASS COMMENTS DESIGN, SPEED, MPH MINIMUM R.O.W. WIDTH, MINIMUM PAVEMENT WIDTH,

3.6.5  Pavement Section.
   The type of pavement is dependent on the number, weight and speed of
vehicles expected. Obviously, the more load expected on the pavement, the
stronger the pavement section must be. Typically, the pavement section consists
of several parts: existing base, subgrade, pavement, pavement surface, and
drainage features. The existing base is the native earth material that is
either cut or carefully compacted into place to form the general shape of the
roadway. It is hoped that the existing base can carry most of loading placed on
the pavement. The subgrade is a modified soil, asphalt or concrete layer above
the existing base used to make up for bearing deficiencies in the existing base
and to provide a relatively smooth surface for the pavement. The pavement is a
protective topping for the subgrade and existing base to prevent erosion and
saturation by water (since most earthen materials will eventually break down in
the presence of water). In many cases, the pavement also provides some loading
support. The pavement surface is designed to facilitate vehicle movement by
minimizing friction but still providing sufficient friction for vehicle tire
stability. If the pavement is the "roof for the pavement section, then the
ditches, gutters and storm sewer system are the gutter system necessary to
carry the drainage water away from the roadway where it cannot cause problems.
   Existing base materials are any native material, with rocky material
generally being the most stable and clay materials being the least stable.
Subgrade materials usually consist of crushed limestone, lime or cement treated
natural materials, asphaltic concrete or other load spreading materials. The
pavement generally consists of reinforced concrete, hot mixed asphalt concrete,
or penetration asphalt pavement. Depending on existing base materials, thicker
sections may be required.
   In general, streets experiencing high traffic volumes or heavy trucks shall
be made of reinforced concrete and be curb and guttered. Other nonresidential
streets can be either reinforced concrete or hot mix asphalt. Major and minor
residential streets shall be hot mixed asphalt when street is curbed but may be
two-course penetration pavement when streets are not curbed.
   The City Engineer shall approve all street designs. The designer shall
submit geotechnical data with the design to validate the sections proposed. The
following is a table of minimum designs. Designs less than these minimums will
not be considered.
 
Roadway Class     Minimum Wheel  Minimum Asphalt      Minimum Reinforced
                  Loading (lbs.) Section              Concrete Section
                                 2" Class D HMAC 8"   8" - Class "C" RC 6"

                                 Subgrade
